sen.j: 狩野派（かのうは）は、日本絵画史上最大の画派であり、室町時代中期（15世紀）から江戸時代末期（19世紀）まで、約400年にわたって活動し、常に画壇の中心にあった専門画家集団である。
sen.e: The Kanoha group is the biggest Gaha group of the Japanese painting in history, and was active for about 400 years from the middle of the Muromachi era (15th century) to the end of the Edo era (19th century), as an expert painter group consistently dominating the art world.

The Kanoha group is the largest gaha (group of Japanese painters) in history, and was active for about 400 years from the middle of the Muromachi period (fifteenth century) to the end of the Edo period (nineteenth century) as an expert painter group that consistently dominated the art world.

The Kanoha group is the largest gaha (group of painters) in Japanese art history, and was active for about 400 years from the middle of the Muromachi period (fifteenth century) to the end of the Edo period (nineteenth century) as a group of expert painters that consistently dominated the art world.

sen.j: 室町幕府の御用絵師となった狩野正信を始祖とし、その子孫は、室町幕府崩壊後は織田信長、豊臣秀吉、徳川将軍などに絵師として仕え、その時々の権力者と結び付いて常に画壇の中心を占め、内裏、城郭、大寺院などの障壁画から扇面などの小画面に至るまで、あらゆるジャンルの絵画を手掛ける職業画家集団として、日本美術界に多大な影響を及ぼした。
sen.e: Masanobu KANO, the Official painter of the Muromachi Shogunate, was the earliest ancestor, and his descendants worked for Nobunaga ODA, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and Tokugawa Shogun as painters after collapse of the Muromachi Shogunate, consistently dominating the art world tied up with the powers-that-be, and greatly influenced Japanese art circles as a professional painter group working on various kinds of paintings from paintings on partitions in Imperial palace, castles or big temples to small paintings such as a face of fan.

Masanobu Kano, the official painter of the Muromachi shogunate, was the earliest ancestor; his descendants worked for Nobunaga Oda, Hideyoshi Toyotomi and the Tokugawa Shogun as painters after the collapse of the Muromachi shogunate, consistently dominating the art world tied up with the powers-that-be, thus greatly influencing Japanese art circles as a professional painter group working on various kinds of paintings from paintings on partitions in the Imperial Palace, castles or large temples to small paintings such as created on the faces of fans.

Masanobu KANO, the official painter of the Muromachi shogunate, was the earliest ancestor; his descendants worked for Nobunaga ODA, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI and the Tokugawa Shogun as painters after the collapse of the Muromachi shogunate, consistently dominating the art world associated with the powers-that-be, thus greatly influencing Japanese art circles as a professional painter group working on works ranging from screen paintings in the Imperial Palace, castles or large temples to small paintings such as those created on fans.

sen.j: 狩野派は、親・兄弟などの血族関係を主軸とした画家集団で、約4世紀間の長期にわたって一国の画壇に君臨したという点で、世界的にも他にほとんど例を見ないものである。
sen.e: The Kanoha group is a painter group mainly with consanguinity such as parents or brothers, and reigned over the art world of a nation for as long as 4 centuries, which is unequaled anywhere in the world.

The Kanoha group is a painter group mainly concerned with consanguinity such as parents or brothers; it reigned over the nation's realm of art for as long as four centuries, a period unequaled anywhere in the world.

The Kanoha group is a painter group mainly concerned with consanguinity such as parents or brothers; it reigned over the nation's realm of art for as long as four centuries, a period unequaled anywhere in the world.

sen.j: 狩野派の代表的な絵師としては、室町幕府8代将軍足利義政に仕えた初代狩野正信とその嫡男・狩野元信、元信の孫で安土城や大坂城の障壁画を制作した狩野永徳、永徳の孫で京都から江戸に本拠を移し、江戸城、二条城などの障壁画制作を指揮した狩野探幽、京都にとどまって「京狩野」と称された一派を代表する狩野山楽などが挙げられる。
sen.e: Prominent painters of the Kanoha group include the founder Masanobu KANO, who worked for Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, the 8th Shogun of the Muromachi Shogunate; his heir, Motonobu KANO; a grandson of Motonobu, Eitoku KANO, who created paintings on partitions of Azuchi Castle and Osaka Castle; a grandson of Eitoku, Tan'yu KANO, who moved from Kyoto to Edo and supervised creation of paintings on partitions of Edo Castle and Nijo Castle; Sanraku KANO who stayed in Kyoto, representing a group called "Kyo Kano'.

Prominent painters of the Kanoha group include the founder Masanobu Kano, who worked for Yoshimasa Ashikaga, the eighth shogun of the Muromachi shogunate; his heir, Motonobu Kano, a grandson of Motonobu; Eitoku Kano, who created paintings on the partitions of the Azuchi and Osaka castles; a grandson of Eitoku, Tan'yu Kano, who moved from Kyoto to Edo and supervised the creation of paintings on partitions of Edo Castle and Nijo Castle; Sanraku Kano, who stayed in Kyoto, representing a group called "Kyo Kano."

Prominent painters of the Kanoha group include the founder Masanobu KANO, who worked for Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, the eighth Seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") of the Muromachi shogunate; his heir, Motonobu KANO, a grandson of Motonobu; Eitoku KANO, who created screen paintings of the Azuchi and Osaka castles; a grandson of Eitoku, Tanyu KANO, who moved from Kyoto to Edo and supervised the creation of screen paintings of Edo Castle and Nijo Castle; Sanraku KANO, who stayed in Kyoto, thus representing a group called 'Kyo Kano.'

sen.j: 江戸幕府の体制が安定して以後の狩野派は、幕府の御用絵師として、内裏、城郭などの障壁画の大量注文をこなす必要に迫られた。
sen.e: After the structure of the Edo Shogunate stabilized, the Kanoha group were driven to get extensive order done for paintings on partitions of the Imperial palace and castles as Official painters of the Shogunate.

Once the structure of the Edo shogunate had become stable, the members of the Kanoha group were driven to get extensive orders done for paintings on partitions of the Imperial Palace and castles as the shogunate's official painters.

Once the structure of the Edo shogunate had become stable, the members of the Kanoha group were driven to get extensive orders done for screen paintings of the Imperial Palace and castles as the shogunate's official painters.

sen.j: 膨大な量の障壁画の注文に応えるため、狩野家の当主は、一門の絵師たちを率いて集団で制作にあたる必要があった。
sen.e: In order to fill a vast amount of orders of paintings on partitions, the family head of the Kano Family needed to lead the painters of the sept to work in a group.
In order to fulfill large numbers of orders for paintings on partitions, the head of the Kano Family needed to lead the painters so they could work in a group.
In order to fulfill large numbers of orders for screen paintings, the head of the Kano family needed to lead the painters so they could work in a group.

sen.j: そのため、狩野派の絵師には、絵師個人の個性の表出ではなく、先祖伝来の粉本（絵手本）や筆法を忠実に学ぶことが求められた。
sen.e: Therefore, the painters of the Kanoha group needed to learn ancestral painting examples and way of painting, without expressing individuality of a painter.
Consequently, the painters of the Kanoha group needed to learn ancestral painting examples and ways of painting without expressing their individuality as painters.
Consequently, the painters of the Kanoha group needed to learn ancestral painting examples and ways of painting without expressing their individuality as painters.

sen.j: こうした時代背景から、狩野探幽以降の狩野派は伝統の維持と御用絵師としての勢力保持にもっぱら努め、芸術的創造性を失っていったという見方もある。
sen.e: In such historical backdrop, it can be said that the Kanoha group after Tan'yu KANO only tried to keep the tradition and to maintain the influence as Official painters.
Given such an historical backdrop, it can be said that the Kanoha group after Tan'yu Kano only tried to keep the tradition and maintain influence as official painters.

Given such an historical backdrop, it can be said that the Kanoha group after Tanyu KANO only tried to keep the tradition and maintain influence as official painters, and therefore lost its artistic drive.

sen.j: 芸術家の個性の表現や内面の表出を尊重する現代において、狩野派の絵画への評価は必ずしも高いとは言えない。
sen.e: At the present day, expression of individuality and mentality of an artist is highly regarded, so the evaluation of paintings of the Kanoha group is not necessarily high.
In the present day, an artist's expression of individuality and mentality is valued, so the evaluation of paintings of the Kanoha group is not necessarily high.

sen.j: しかしながら、狩野派が約4世紀にわたって日本の画壇をリードし、そこから多くの画家が育っていったことも事実であり、良きにつけ悪しきにつけ、狩野派を抜きにして日本の絵画史を語ることはできない。
sen.e: However, it is a fact that the Kanoha group led Japanese art world for about 4 centuries and numbers of painters were developed by the group, and we can hardly discuss about Japanese painting history without the Kanoha group, whether it's good or bad.

sen.j: 近世以降の日本の画家の多くが狩野派の影響を受け、狩野派の影響から出発したことも事実であり、琳派の尾形光琳、写生派の円山応挙なども初期には狩野派に学んでいる。
sen.e: It is also a fact that many Japanese painters after early modern ages were influenced by the Kanoha group and started from the influence of the Kanoha group, and Korin OGATA from the Rimpa group and Okyo MARUYAMA from the Shaseiha group learned from the Kanoha group in the beginning.

sen.j: 20世紀後半以降の研究の進展により、狩野家は下野国足利（栃木県足利市）の長尾氏と何らかの関係があったものと推定されており、足利市の長林寺に残る墨画の『観瀑図』は正信の比較的初期の作品と考えられている。
sen.e: Due to the progress of the study after the late 20th century, it is speculated that the Kano Family were somehow related to the Nagao clan in Ashikaga, Shimotsuke-no-kuni (Ashikaga City, Tochigi Prefecture), and "Waterfall," an ink painting remained in Chorin-ji Temple in Ashikaga city is considered to be Masanobu's comparatively early work.

sen.j: 正信の画業として記録に残る最初の事例は、応仁の乱（1467 - 1477）の直前の寛正4年（1463年）、30歳の時に京都の雲頂院（相国寺塔頭）に観音と羅漢図の壁画を制作したというもので（『蔭涼軒日録』所載）、この時点で正信がすでに京都において画家として活動していたことがわかる。
sen.e: The first case retained for record as Masanobu's painting work is creation of the paintings on partitions of Deity of Mercy and Luohan in Unchoin, Shokoku-ji Temple Tower in Kyoto at the age of 30 in 1463 right before the turmoil of the Onin war (1467 - 1477) (reported in "Inryoken-Nichiroku Diary"), from which we can see Masanobu already worked as a painter in Kyoto at this point.

The first painting work recorded as having been done by Masanobu is the screen paintings he did of the Deity of Mercy and Luohan in Unchoin, Shokoku-ji Temple Tower, which he did in Kyoto at the age of 30 in 1463. This was just before the turmoil of the Onin War (1467 - 1477) (as reported in Inryoken Nichiroku (Inryoken's Diary)), which tells us that Masanobu was already working as a painter in Kyoto by that time.

sen.j: 現存する代表作は大徳寺大仙院方丈の障壁画（方丈は永正10年（1513年）に完成）、天文 (元号)12年（1543年）の妙心寺霊雲院障壁画などである（大仙院障壁画については、方丈竣工時の作品ではなく、やや後の年代の作とする見方が有力である）。
sen.e: His existing best works include the paintings on partitions in Hojo of Daisenin, Daitoku-ji Temple (the Hojo was completed in 1513) and another one in Reiun'in, Myoshin-ji Temple in 1543 (it is widely believed that the paintings on partitions in Daisenin was not the work at the time of completion of Hojo, but the work in a little later era).

His best existing works include the paintings on partitions in Hojo of Daisenin, Daitoku-ji Temple (the Hojo was completed in 1513) and another one in Reiun'in, Myoshin-ji Temple in 1543 (it is widely believed that the paintings on partitions in Daisenin were not created at the time of the completion of Hojo but were done in a slightly later period).

His best existing works include the screen paintings in the hojo of Daisenin, Daitoku-ji Temple (the hojo, or chief priest's room, was completed in 1513) and another one in Reiunin, Myoshin-ji Temple in 1543 (it is widely believed that the screen paintings in Daisenin were not created at the time the hojo was completed but were done in a slightly later period).

sen.j: 大仙院方丈障壁画は相阿弥、元信と弟・狩野之信が部屋ごとに制作を分担しており、元信が担当したのは「檀那の間」の『四季花鳥図』と、「衣鉢の間」の『禅宗祖師図』などであった。
sen.e: The creation of the paintings on partitions in Hojo of Daisenin was divided among Soami, Motonobu and his brother Yukinobu KANO depending on rooms, and Motonobu took charge of "Four Seasons, Flowers and Birds" in "Danna no Ma" and "Founder of Zenshu sect" in "Ihatsu no Ma."

The creation of the paintings on partitions in Hojo of Daisenin was divided among Soami, Motonobu and his brother Yukinobu Kano, depending on the rooms; accordingly, Motonobu took charge of "Four Seasons, Flowers and Birds" in "Danna no Ma" and "Founder of Zenshu sect" in "Ihatsu no Ma."

The creation of the screen paintings in the hojo of Daisenin was divided among Soami, Motonobu and his brother Yukinobu KANO, depending on the room; accordingly, Motonobu took charge of "Four Seasons, Flowers and Birds" in 'Danna no Ma' and "Founder of the Zenshu sect" in 'Ihatsu no Ma.'
sen.cmt: 括弧修正苗字を大文字にしました。"paintings on partitions" → "screen paintings"

sen.j: このうち、『禅宗祖師図』は典型的な水墨画であるが、『四季花鳥図』は水墨を基調としつつ、草花や鳥の部分にのみ濃彩を用いて新しい感覚を示している。
sen.e: "Zen Patriarchs" is a typical ink painting, while "Birds and Flowers of the Four Seasons" is based on ink and also shows a new taste at the same time using colors only on flowers and birds.

sen.j: 元信は時の権力者であった足利将軍や細川家との結び付きを強め、多くの門弟を抱えて、画家集団としての狩野派の基盤を確かなものにした。
sen.e: Motonobu strengthened the ties with the Ashikaga Shogun and the Hosokawa clan as the powers-that-be, had numbers of disciples, and consolidated the basis of the Kanoha group as a painter group.
Motonobu strengthened the ties with the Ashikaga shogun and the Hosokawa clan as the powers-that-be, had numerous disciples and consolidated the basis of the Kanoha as a group of painters.

sen.j: 武家だけでなく、公家、寺社などからの注文にも応え、寺社関係では、大坂にあった石山本願寺の障壁画を元信が手掛けたことが記録から分かっているが、これは現存しない。
sen.e: He accepted orders from court nobles, and temples and shrines as well as samurai families, and as for temples and shrines, it is known that he created the paintings on partitions of Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple in Osaka according to records, but this does not exist any more.

He accepted orders from court nobles, temples and shrines as well as samurai families; and as for temples and shrines it is known that he created the paintings on the partitions of Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple in Osaka according to the historical record, but this no longer exists.

He accepted orders from court nobles, temples and shrines as well as samurai families; and as for temples and shrines it is known that he created the screen paintings of Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple in Osaka according to the historical record, but this no longer exists.

sen.j: 元信は晩年には「越前守」を名乗り、また「法眼（ほうげん）」という僧位を与えられたことから、後世には「古法眼」「越前法眼」などと称されている。
sen.e: Since Motonobu called himself "Echizen no kami" in his later life, and he was given a priestly rank called "Hogen," he was referred to as "Kohogen" and "Echizen Hogen" by posterity.

Because Motonobu referred to himself as "Echizen no kami" in his later life, and he was given a priestly rank called "Hogen" however, for posterity he has been referred to as "Kohogen" or "Echizen Hogen."

sen.j: 作品のレパートリーは幅広く、障壁画のほか、寺社の縁起絵巻、絵馬、大和絵風の金屏風、肖像画なども手掛けている。
sen.e: The range of his work is wide, and he created Engi Emaki of temples and shrines, votive pictures, gilded folding screens in Yamatoe style, and portraits as well as paintings on partitions.
The work is wide-ranging: he created the Engi Emaki of temples and shrines, votive pictures, gilded folding screens in the Yamatoe style, and portraits as well as paintings on partitions.

sen.j: 元信は父正信の得意とした漢画、水墨画に大和絵の画法を取り入れ、襖、屏風などの装飾的な大画面を得意とし、狩野派様式の基礎を築いた。
sen.e: Motonobu took Yamatoe painting style in Kanga and ink painting which his father Masanobu specialized in, and he specialized in big decorative paintings such as a Fusuma (Japanese sliding door) and a screen, and built a foundation of the Kanoha group's style.

Motonobu took the Yamatoe painting style in Kanga and ink painting (in which his father Masanobu specialized); he specialized in large decorative paintings such as a Fusuma (Japanese sliding door) and a screen, and built a foundation for the Kanoha group's style.

Motonobu assumed the Yamatoe painting style in Kanga and ink painting (in which his father Masanobu specialized); he specialized in large decorative paintings such as a Fusuma (Japanese sliding door) and a folding screen, and built a foundation for the style of the Kanoha group.

sen.j: また、書道の楷書、行書、草書にならって、絵画における「真体、行体、草体」という画体の概念を確立し、近世障壁画の祖とも言われている。
sen.e: He is also called the founder of the early modern paintings on partitions, since he established the concept of painting types as "true type, semi-cursive type and cursive type" in paintings, after the examples of standard script, semi-cursive script and cursive script in calligraphy.

He is also called the founder of the early modern paintings on partitions, given that he established the concept of painting types as "true type, semi-cursive type and cursive type" in paintings, after the examples of standard script, semi-cursive script and cursive script in calligraphy.

He is also called the founder of the early modern screen paintings as he established the concept of calligraphy painting styles such as Shintai (standard style), Gyotai (semi-cursive style), and Sotai (cursive style).

sen.j: 元信には宗信、秀頼、直信の3人の男子があったが、長男の宗信は早世したため、宗家を継いだのは三男の直信（1519 - 1592）であった。
sen.e: Motonobu had three sons, Munenobu, Hideyori and Naonobu; Naonobu (1519 - 1592), the third son succeeded the head family since the first son Munenobu died young.
Motonobu had three sons: Munenobu, Hideyori and Naonobu; Naonobu (1519 - 1592); the first, Munenobu, died young, and the third son Naonobu succeeded as the head of family.

sen.e: Naonobu is widely known as Shoei KANO, his posthumous name, and was active from the Muromachi to Momoyama era.

sen.j: また、父・元信とともに石山本願寺障壁画制作に参加しており、大徳寺聚光院（じゅこういん）障壁画制作には息子の永徳とともに参加しているが、父・元信と息子・永徳がそれぞれに高名であるために、やや地味な存在となっている。
sen.e: Though he joined creation of the paintings on partitions of Ishiyama Hongan-ji Temple with his father Motonobu, and also joined creation of the painting on partitions of Jukoin, Daitoku-ji Temple with his son Eitoku, he is undistinguished because his father Motonobu and his son Eitoku are prominent.

sen.j: 松栄の嫡男・狩野永徳（1543 - 1590）は州信（くにのぶ）とも称し、桃山時代の日本画壇を代表する人物である。
sen.e: The heir of Shoei, Eitoku KANO (1543 - 1590) is also called Kuninobu, and one of the most distinguished painters of the Japanese art world in the Momoyama era.

sen.j: 織田信長、豊臣秀吉といった乱世を生き抜いた権力者の意向に敏感に応え、多くの障壁画を描いたが、これら障壁画は建物とともに消滅し、現存する永徳の作品は比較的少ない。
sen.e: Though he created numbers of paintings on partitions in acutely complying with the plans of the men in power surviving wild times including Nobunaga ODA and Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, these paintings were lost with the buildings, and existing Eitoku's works are relatively little.

Though he created numbers of paintings on partitions in strict compliance with the plans of the men in power who had survived wild times--including Nobunaga Oda and Hideyoshi Toyotomi--these paintings were lost with the buildings, so relatively few of Eitoku's works still exist.

sen.j: 現存する代表作の一つである大徳寺聚光院方丈障壁画は永徳と父・松栄の分担制作であるが、父・松栄は方丈南側正面の主要な部屋の襖絵を息子の永徳にまかせ、自分は脇役に回っている。
sen.e: The paintings on partitions in Hojo of Jukoin, Daitoku-ji Temple as one of his best existing work were created by Eitoku together with his father Shoei, but Shoei had his son Eitoku take charge of Fusumae of the major room in the south front of Hojo, and he took a supporting part himself.

The paintings on the partitions in the hojo of Jukoin, Daitoku-ji Temple (which are among his best existing works) were created by Eitoku together with his father Shoei; however, Shoei had Eitoku take charge of Fusumae of the major room in the south front of the hojo, while he took a supporting role.

The paintings on the partitions in the hojo of Jukoin, Daitoku-ji Temple (which are among his best existing works) were created by Eitoku together with his father Shoei; however, Shoei had Eitoku take charge of Fusumae of the major room in the south front of the hojo, while he took a supporting role.

sen.j: 封建社会の当時にあっては、家門の長が主要な部屋の襖絵を描くのが常識であり、この障壁画制作時には松栄は才能豊かな永徳に家督を譲って、自身はすでに隠居の身であったと考証されている。
sen.e: In those feudal society days, it was common practice that the head of a family would create Fusumae in the major room, so it is historically believed that, at the time of creation of the paintings, Shoei was already retired after transferring the family estate to Eitoku with great talent.

sen.j: 永徳は細画（さいが）と大画（たいが）のいずれをも得意としたが、大量の障壁画の注文をこなすために、大画様式で描かざるをえなかったという。

sen.j: 狩野家直系以外の絵師としては、川越・喜多院の『職人尽図屏風』の筆者である狩野吉信（1552 - 1640）、京都・豊国神社 (京都市)の『豊国祭図屏風』の筆者である狩野内膳（1570 - 1616）らが知られる。
sen.e: As painters other than the direct line of the Kano Family, Yoshinobu KANO (1552 - 1640) who painted "Craftspeople, folding screen" in Kitain, Kawagoe City, and Naizen KANO (1570 - 1616) who painted "Hokoku Festival, folding screen" in Kyoto Toyokuni-jinja Shrine (Kyoto City) are well known.

As painters other than the direct line of the Kano Family, Yoshinobu Kano (1552 - 1640) who painted "Craftspeople, folding screen" in Kitain, Kawagoe City, and Naizen Kano (1570 - 1616), who painted "Hokoku Festival, folding screen" in Kyoto Toyokuni-jinja Shrine (Kyoto City) are well known.

As painters other than the direct line of the Kano family, Yoshinobu KANO (1552 - 1640), who painted "Craftspeople, folding screen" in Kawagoe Kitain, and Naizen KANO (1570 - 1616), who painted "Hokoku Festival, folding screen" in Kyoto Toyokuni-jinja Shrine (Kyoto City), are well known.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 狩野永徳は父の松栄（直信）に先立って48歳で没した。
sen.e: Eitoku KANO died at 48 before his father Shoei (Naonobu) died.
Eitoku Kano died at age 48, before his father Shoei (Naonobu) died.
Eitoku KANO died at age 48, preceding his father Shoei (Naonobu).
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: その後を継いだのは永徳の長男・狩野光信（1565? - 1608）と次男・狩野孝信（1571 - 1618）である。
sen.e: Eitoku's first son Mitsunobu KANO (1565? - 1608) and second son Takanobu KANO (1571 - 1618) succeeded him.
Eitoku's first son Mitsunobu Kano (1565? - 1608) and second son Takanobu Kano (1571 - 1618) succeeded him.
Eitoku's first son Mitsunobu KANO (c. 1565 - 1608) and second son Takanobu KANO (1571 - 1618) succeeded him.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。c. を追加

sen.j: 光信は、園城寺勧学院客殿障壁画などを残し、永徳とは対照的な、大和絵風の繊細な画風を特色とした。
sen.e: Mitsunobu created the paintings on partitions in Reception Hall of Kangakuin, Onjo-ji Temple, and he specialized in delicate painting in Yamatoe style in contrast to Eitoku.
Mitsunobu created the paintings on partitions in the Reception Hall of Kangakuin, Onjo-ji Temple; in contrast to Eitoku he specialized in delicate painting in the Yamatoe style.
Mitsunobu created the screen paintings in the Reception Hall of Kangakuin, Onjo-ji Temple; in contrast to Eitoku he specialized in delicate painting in the Yamatoe style.

sen.j: こうした画風が制作当時の一般的な好みに合致しなかったためか、『本朝画史』などの近世の画論は一様に光信を低く評価している。
sen.e: Such painting style might not have suited the public taste of the time, and the early modern essays on paintings including "Honchogashi" generally put a low value on Mitsunobu.
Such a style of painting might not have suited the public taste at the time, and the early modern essays on paintings, including "Honchogashi," generally put a low value on Mitsunobu.
Such a style of painting might not have suited the public taste at the time, and the early modern essays on paintings, including "Honchogashi," generally put a low value on Mitsunobu.

sen.j: 狩野家の頭領である光信が死去した時、その子の狩野貞信（1597 - 1623）はまだ12歳の若年であったので、光信の弟である孝信が狩野派を率いることとなった。
sen.e: After Mitsunobu, the head of the Kano Family died, his brother Takanobu led the Kanoha group because his son Sadanobu KANO (1597 - 1623) was young and only 12.
After the death of Mitsunobu, the head of the Kano Family, his brother Takanobu led the Kanoha group because his son Sadanobu Kano (1597 - 1623) was only 12 years of age.
After the death of the Kano ｆamily head Mitsunobu, his brother Takanobu led the Kanoha group because his son Sadanobu KANO (1597 - 1623) was only 12 years of age.

sen.j: 封建制度の下では、光信の長男である貞信の家系が宗家となるはずであったが、貞信が27歳で早世し後継ぎがなかったため、以後、幕末に至る狩野家の正系は孝信の子孫となっている。
sen.e: Under the feudal system, the family line of Sadanobu, Mitsunobu's first son was supposed to be the head family, but Sadanobu died young at the age of 27 without any heir, so after that, the legitimacy of the Kano Family was the descendant of Takanobu to the end of the Edo era.

Under the feudal system, the family line of Sadanobu, Mitsunobu's first son, was supposed to be the head of family; however, Sadanobu died without an heir at the age of just 27, so after that the legitimacy of the Kano Family was the descendant of Takanobu till the end of the Edo period.

Under the feudal system, the family line of Sadanobu, Mitsunobu's first son, was supposed to be the head of family; however, Sadanobu died without an heir at the age of just 27, so after that the legitimacy of the Kano family was the descendant of Takanobu till the end of the Edo period.

sen.j: 孝信には守信（探幽、1602 - 1674）、狩野尚信（1607 - 1650）、狩野安信（1613 - 1685）の3人の男子があり、この3人はそれぞれ鍛冶橋狩野家、木挽町（こびきちょう）狩野家、中橋狩野家（宗家）の祖となった。
sen.e: Takanobu had 3 sons - Morinobu (Tan'yu 1602 - 1674), Naonobu KANO (1607 - 1650) and Yasunobu KANO (1613 - 1685), and they respectively became the earliest ancestor of the Kajibashi Kano Family, Kobikicho Kano Family and Nakabashi Kano Family.

Takanobu had three sons--Morinobu (Tan'yu 1602 - 1674), Naonobu Kano (1607 - 1650) and Yasunobu Kano (1613 - 1685)--and they respectively became the earliest ancestor of the Kajibashi Kano Family, Kobikicho Kano Family and Nakabashi Kano Family.

Takanobu had three sons--Morinobu (Tanyu 1602 - 1674), Naonobu KANO (1607 - 1650) and Yasunobu KANO(1613 - 1685)--and they respectively became the earliest ancestor of the Kajibashi Kano family, Kobikicho Kano family and Nakabashi Kano family.

sen.j: 末弟の安信は前述の貞信の養子という扱いで狩野の宗家を継ぐことになったが、絵師として最も名高いのは探幽こと守信である。
sen.e: Though the youngest son Yasunobu succeeded the head family of Kano as an adopted son of Sadanobu mentioned above, the most renowned painter is Morinobu also known as Tan'yu.
Though the youngest son, Yasunobu, succeeded as the Kano head of family as an adopted son of Sadanobu (mentioned above), the most renowned painter was Morinobu (also known as Tanyu).
Although the youngest son, Yasunobu, succeeded as the Kano head of family as an adopted son of Sadanobu (mentioned above), the most renowned painter was Morinobu (also known as Tanyu).

sen.j: 守信は、後に出家して探幽斎と称し、画家としては狩野探幽の名で知られる。
sen.e: Morinobu later became a priest and called himself Tan'yusai, and he is known as Tan'yu KANO as a painter.
Morinobu later became a priest and called himself Tan'yusai; he is known as Tan'yu Kano as a painter.
Morinobu later became a priest and called himself Tanyusai; as a painter he is known as Tanyu KANO.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 後に江戸に本拠を移し、江戸幕府の御用絵師として、画壇における狩野派の地位をますます不動のものとした。
sen.e: Later, he moved to Edo, and solidified the position of the Kanoha group in the art world more as the Official painter of the Edo Shogunate.
He eventually moved to Edo and solidified the position of the Kanoha group in the art world more as the official painter of the Edo shogunate.
He eventually moved to Edo and solidified the position of the Kanoha group in the art world more as the official painter of the Edo shogunate.

sen.j: 探幽は幼少時より画才を発揮し、慶長17年（1612年）、11歳の時に駿府で徳川家康に対面、元和 (日本)7年（1621年）には江戸鍛冶橋門外に屋敷を得て、以後江戸を拠点に活動し、城郭や大寺院などの障壁画を精力的に制作した。
sen.e: Tan'yu exercised his painting talent from childhood and he met Ieyasu TOKUGAWA in Sump at the age of 11, and he got a residence in Edo Kajibashi Mongai in 1621, since then worked based in Edo, and energetically created paintings on partitions in castles or big temples.

Tan'yu exercised his painting talent from childhood; and he met Ieyasu Tokugawa in Sump at the age of 11 and obtained a residence in Edo Kajibashi Mongai in 1621, subsequent to which he worked based in Edo and energetically created paintings on partitions in castles and large temples.

Tanyu exercised his painting talent from childhood; in 1612, he met Ieyasu TOKUNAGA in Sunpu at the age of 11 and obtained a residence in Edo Kajibashi Mongai in 1621, subsequent to which he worked based in Edo and energetically created screen paintings in castles and large temples.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。"paintings on partitions" → "screen paintings""in 1612," を追加しました。

sen.j: 探幽の作品のうち、江戸城と大坂城の障壁画は建物とともに消滅したが、名古屋城上洛殿の障壁画（水墨）は第二次大戦時には建物から取り外して疎開させてあったため空襲をまぬがれて現存しており、他に二条城二の丸御殿や大徳寺方丈の障壁画が現存する代表作である。
sen.e: Among Tan'yu's works, the paintings on partitions in Edo Castle and Osaka Castle are lost with the buildings, but the paintings on partitions (ink painting) in Jorakuden of Nagoya Castle are existent having avoided an air raid at World War II because they had been removed from the building and evacuated, and the paintings on partitions in Ninomaru Palace of Nijo Castle and Hojo of Daitoku-ji Temple are also his existing best works.

Among Tan'yu's works, the paintings on partitions in the Edo and Osaka castles were lost with the buildings, but the paintings on partitions (ink paintings) in Jorakuden of Nagoya Castle are existent, having avoided an air raid during World War II because they had been removed from the building and evacuated; additionally, the paintings on partitions in Ninomaru Palace of Nijo Castle and the hojo of Daitoku-ji Temple are among his best existent works.

Among Tanyu's works, the screen paintings in the Edo and Osaka castles were lost with the buildings, but the screen paintings (ink paintings) in Jorakuden of Nagoya Castle are existent, having avoided an air raid during World War II because they had been removed from the building and evacuated; additionally, the screen paintings in Ninomaru Palace of Nijo Castle and the hojo of Daitoku-ji Temple are among his best existent works.

sen.j: これら大画面のほかにも、掛軸、絵巻、屏風などあらゆるジャンルの作品を残している。
sen.e: He created various kinds of works including hanging rolls, picture scrolls and folding screens as well as these big paintings.
He created various kinds of works, including hanging rolls, picture scrolls and folding screens, as well as these large paintings.
He created various kinds of works, including hanging rolls, picture scrolls and folding screens, as well as these large paintings.

sen.j: 二条城二の丸御殿障壁画は25歳の若描きで、永徳風の豪壮な画風を示すが、後年の大徳寺の障壁画は水墨を主体とし、余白をたっぷりと取った穏やかな画風のものである。
sen.e: He created the paintings on partitions in Ninomaru Palace of Nijo Castle when he was young at 25 and they showed dynamism in Eitoku's style, but the paintings on partitions in Daitoku-ji Temple he created later in his life mainly with ink and water have calm painting style with full of blank space.

He created the paintings on partitions in Ninomaru Palace of Nijo Castle when he was young (25 years of age), and they showed dynamism in Eitoku's style; however, the paintings on partitions in Daitoku-ji Temple, which he created later in his life (mainly with ink and water), display a calm approach with abundant use of blank space.

He created the screen paintings in Ninomaru Palace of Nijo Castle when he was young (25 years of age), and they showed dynamism in Eitoku's style; however, the screen paintings in Daitoku-ji Temple, which he created later in his life (mainly with ink and water), display a calm approach with abundant use of blank space.

sen.j: 絵巻や屏風には大和絵風の作品もある。
sen.e: He had works in Yamatoe style in picture scrolls and folding screens as well.
He had works in the Yamatoe style in picture scrolls and folding screens as well.
He had works in the Yamatoe style in picture scrolls and folding screens as well.

sen.j: 探幽は写生（スケッチ）や古画の模写を重視し、写生図集や模写画集を多数残している。
sen.e: Tan'yu emphasized sketches and copying out ancient paintings, and left numbers of sketch books and reproduction books.
Tan'yu emphasized sketches and the copying of ancient paintings; consequently, he left numerous sketch books and reproduction books.
Tanyu emphasized sketches and the copying of ancient paintings; consequently, he left numerous sketch books and reproduction books.

sen.j: 「探幽縮図」と称される探幽筆の古画模写は多数現存しており、各地の美術館や収集家が所蔵しているが、これらには今日では原画が失われてしまった古画の模写も多数含まれており、日本絵画史研究上、貴重な資料となっている。
sen.e: Many of Tan'yu's copies of ancient paintings called "Tan'yu Reduction" are existent, which museums and collectors around the nation have, and they include lots of copies of ancient paintings whose originals are now lost, so they are valuable data for study of Japanese art history.

Many of Tan'yu's copies of ancient paintings (called "Tan'yu Reduction") are existent, which are now part of museums and collections around the nation, and they include many copies of ancient paintings whose originals are now lost, so they are valuable as data for the study of Japanese art history.

Many of Tanyu's copies of ancient paintings (called 'Tanyu Reduction') are existent, which are now part of museums and collections around the nation, and they include many copies of ancient paintings whose originals are now lost, so they are valuable as data for the study of Japanese art history.

tit.e: Middle of Edo Era and Later
The Middle Edo Period and Later
The Middle Edo Period and Later

sen.j: 江戸時代の狩野派は、狩野家の宗家を中心とした血族集団と、全国にいる多数の門人からなる巨大な画家集団であり、ピラミッド型の組織を形成していた。
sen.e: The Kanoha group in the Edo era was a huge painter group composed of a consanguinity group mainly with the head family of the Kano family and numerous disciples around the nation, consisting of a hierarchy.

The Kanoha group during the Edo period was a huge painting group comprised of a consanguinity group mainly with the head family of the Kano family and numerous disciples around the nation, thus comprising a hierarchy.

The Kanoha group during the Edo period was a huge painting group comprised of a consanguinity group mainly with the head family of the Kano family and numerous disciples around the nation, thus comprising a hierarchy.

sen.j: 「奥絵師」と呼ばれる、もっとも格式の高い4家を筆頭に、それに次いで格式の高い「表絵師」が約15家あり、その下には公儀や寺社の画事ではなく、一般町人の需要に応える「町狩野」が位置するというように、明確に格付けがされ、その影響力は日本全国に及んでいた。
sen.e: They are clearly ranked - under the most prestigious 4 families called "Inner Court Painters," there are about 15 families less prestigious called "Outer Court Painters" and then "Machi Kano Painters" who catered to demand of townspeople, not the Imperial court or temples and shrines - and their influence reached nationwide.

They are clearly ranked - under the most prestigious four families (called "inner court painters") there are about 15 families less prestigious called "outer court painters" and then the "Machi Kano painters" who catered to the demands of townspeople instead of the Imperial Court or temples and shrines; thus their influence spread throughout the nation.

They are clearly ranked: under the most prestigious four families (called 'inner court painters') there are about 15 families less prestigious called 'outer court painters' and then the 'Machi Kano painters' who catered to the demands of townspeople instead of the Imperial Court or temples and shrines; and consequently their influence spread throughout the nation.

sen.j: この時代の権力者は封建社会の安定継続を望み、江戸城のような公の場に描かれる絵画は、新奇なものより伝統的な粉本に則って描かれたものが良しとされた。
sen.e: The powers of the time desired stability and continuance of the feudal society, and the paintings for the public places such as Edo Castle were supposed to be painted in style of traditional painting examples, not to be unique.

The powers of the time sought the stability and continuity of feudal society, and the paintings for public places such as Edo Castle were supposed to be painted in the style of traditional painting examples; they were not intended to be unique.

The powers of the time sought the stability and continuity of feudal society, and the paintings for public places such as Edo Castle were supposed to be painted in the style of traditional painting examples; they were not intended to be unique.

sen.j: また、大量の障壁画制作をこなすには、弟子一門を率いて集団で制作する必要があり、集団制作を容易にするためにも絵師個人の個性よりも粉本（絵手本）を学習することが重視された。
sen.e: Creation of numbers of paintings on partitions requires to work in a group with all the disciples, so, in order to make group work easier, learning painting examples was valued more than individuality of a painter.

In order to create numbers of paintings on partitions, one must work in a group with all the disciples; therefore, in order to make group work easier, the ability to learn from painting examples was valued more than one's individuality as a painter.

In order to create numbers of screen paintings, one must work in a group with all the disciples; therefore, in order to make group work easier, the ability to learn from painting examples was valued more than one's individuality as a painter.

sen.j: こうした点から、狩野派の絵画は、個性や新味に乏しいものになっていったことは否めない。
sen.e: In this regard, it's undeniable that the paintings of the Kanoha group lack in individuality and originality.
In this respect it is undeniable that the paintings of the Kanoha group lack individuality and originality.
In this respect it is undeniable that the paintings of the Kanoha group lack individuality and originality.

sen.j: 奥絵師は旗本と同格で、将軍への「お目見え」と帯刀が許されたというから、その格式の高さがうかがえる。
sen.e: They say the Inner Court Painters ranked with Hatamoto and were allowed "audience" to Shogun and belting on a sward, which implies a high status.
It is said that the inner court painters ranked with Hatamoto and were allowed "audience" with the shogun and belting on a sword, which implies a high status.
It is said that the inner court painters ranked with Hatamoto and were allowed 'audience' with the Shogun as well as belting on a sword, which implies a high status.

sen.j: 奥絵師の4家とは探幽（狩野孝信の長男）の系統の鍛冶橋家、尚信（孝信の次男）の系統の木挽町家（当初は「竹川町家」）、安信（孝信の三男）の系統の中橋家、それに狩野岑信（みねのぶ、1662 - 1708）の系統の浜町家である（岑信は、狩野尚信の長男である狩野常信の次男）。
sen.e: The 4 families of the Inner Court Painters are the Kajibashi Family with lineage of Tan'yu (the first son of Takanobu KANO), the Kobikicho Family with lineage of Naonobu (the second son of Takanobu), the Nakabashi Family with lineage of Yasunobu (the third son of Takanobu) and the Hamacho Family with lineage of Minenobu KANO (1662 - 1708) (Minenobu is the second son of Tsunenobu KANO, the first son of Naonobu KANO).

The four families of the inner court painters are the Kajibashi Family, with lineage of Tan'yu (the first son of Takanobu Kano); the Kobikicho Family, with lineage of Naonobu (the second son of Takanobu); the Nakabashi Family with lineage of Yasunobu (the third son of Takanobu); and the Hamacho Family, with lineage of Minenobu Kano (1662 - 1708) (Minenobu is the second son of Tsunenobu Kano, the first son of Naonobu Kano).

The four families of the inner court painters are the Kajibashi family, with lineage of Tanyu (the first son of Takanobu KANO); the Kobikicho family (called Takekawa-cho family at the time), with lineage of Naonobu (the second son of Takanobu); the Nakabashi family with lineage of Yasunobu (the third son of Takanobu); and the Hamacho family, with lineage of Minenobu KANO (1662 - 1708) (Minenobu is the second son of Tsunenobu KANO, the first son of Naonobu KANO).
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。「竹川町家」の訳を補いました。

sen.j: 探幽には初め実子がなかったため、刀剣金工家の後藤立乗の息子の洞雲（狩野益信、1625 - 1694）を養子とした。
sen.e: Since Tan'yu had no child, he adopted Toun (Masunobu KANO 1625 - 1694), the son of Ritsujo GOTO, a swardsmith.
Because Tan'yu had no child, he adopted Toun (Masunobu Kano 1625 - 1694), the son of Ritsujo GOTO, a swordsmith.
Because Tanyu had no child, he adopted Toun (Masunobu KANO 1625 - 1694), the son of Ryujo GOTO, a swordsmith.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。Ritsujo →Ryujo

sen.j: 後に探幽が50歳を過ぎて生まれた実子である狩野守政（1653 - 1718）が跡を継ぐが、この系統からはその後見るべき画家は出なかった。
sen.e: Later, Morimasa KANO (1653 - 1718) who was his biological son born after Tan'yu became 50 succeeded him, but this lineage had no distinguished painter afterward.
Later, Morimasa Kano (1653 - 1718) who was his biological son (born after Tan'yu turned 50) succeeded him, but subsequently this lineage had no distinguished painter.
Later, Morimasa KANO (1653 - 1718) who was his biological son (born after Tanyu turned 50) succeeded him, but subsequently this lineage had no distinguished painter.

sen.j: 探幽には多くの弟子がいたが、中では『夕顔棚納涼図』を残した久隅守景（くすみもりかげ、生没年未詳）が著名である。
sen.e: Among numbers of disciples of Tan'yu, Morikage KUSUMI (date of birth and death unknown) who created "Enjoying the Cool of the Evening Under the Moonflower Trellis" is renowned.
Among the numerous disciples of Tan'yu, Morikage Kusumi (birth and death dates unknown), creator of "Enjoying the Cool of the Evening Under the Moonflower Trellis," is renowned.
Among the numerous disciples of Tanyu, Morikage KUSUMI (birth and death dates unknown), the creator of "Enjoying the Cool of the Evening Under the Moonflower Trellis," is renowned.

sen.j: 守景は何らかの事情で狩野派を破門になり、後には金沢方面で制作したが、経歴について不明な点が多い。
sen.e: Morikage was expelled from the Kanoha group for any reason, and he worked in Kanazawa area later, but his records are not altogether clear.
Morikage was for some reason expelled from the Kanoha group; he worked in the Kanazawa area later, but his records aren't completely clear.

sen.j: 前述のとおり、狩野家の宗家は、探幽の弟・安信の中橋家が継ぐことになった。
sen.e: As stated previously, the head family of Kano was succeeded by the Nakabashi Family of Yasunobu, a brother of Tan'yu.
As stated previously, the head family of Kano was succeeded by the Nakabashi Family of Yasunobu, a brother of Tan'yu.

sen.j: 安信の子の狩野時信（1642 - 1678）は30代で没し、その子の狩野主信（うじのぶ、1675 - 1724）が家督を継ぐが、この系統からもその後目立った画人は出ていない。
sen.e: Tokinobu KANO (1642 - 1678), a son of Yasunobu, died in his 30s, and his son Ujinobu KANO (1675 - 1724) succeeded the family estate, but this lineage had no distinguished painter afterward.

Tokinobu Kano (1642 - 1678), a son of Yasunobu, died in his thirties, and his son Ujinobu Kano (1675 - 1724) succeeded the family estate; however, subsequently this lineage had no distinguished painter.

sen.j: 都会的な画風で人気を博した英一蝶（はなぶさいっちょう、1652 - 1724）は安信の弟子であった。
sen.e: Itcho HANABUSA (1652 - 1724) who was popular with his sophisticated painting style was a disciple of Yasunobu.
Itcho Hanabusa (1652 - 1724), who was popular with his sophisticated painting style, was a disciple of Yasunobu.
Itcho HANABUSA (1652 - 1724), who was popular based on his sophisticated painting style, was a disciple of Yasunobu.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 奥絵師4家の中で、幕末まで比較的高名な画人を輩出したのは、尚信の系統の木挽町家である。
sen.e: The family that produced relatively prominent painters until the end of the Edo era among the 4 Inner Court Painter Families is the Kobikicho Family of Naonobu's lineage.
The family that produced relatively prominent painters until the end of the Edo period among the four families of the inner court painters is the Kobikicho family, of Naonobu's lineage.
The family that produced relatively prominent painters until the end of the Edo period among the four families of the inner court painters is the Kobikicho family, of Naonobu's lineage.

sen.j: この家系からは尚信の嫡男の狩野常信（1636 - 1713）、その子の狩野周信（ちかのぶ、1660 - 1728）と狩野岑信（みねのぶ、1662 - 1708）らが出ている。
sen.e: This family line produced Tsunenobu KANO (1636 - 1713), the heir of Naonobu, and Tsunenobu's sons, Chikanobu KANO (1660 - 1728) and Minenobu KANO (1662 - 1708).
This family line produced Tsunenobu Kano (1636 - 1713), the heir of Naonobu, and Tsunenobu's sons, Chikanobu Kano (1660 - 1728) and Minenobu Kano (1662 - 1708).
This family line produced Tsunenobu KANO (1636 - 1713), the heir of Naonobu, and Tsunenobu's sons, Chikanobu KANO (1660 - 1728) and Minenobu KANO (1662 - 1708).
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 岑信は将軍・徳川家宣の寵愛を受け、後に「浜町家」として独立し、「奥絵師家」の1つに数えられるようになった。
sen.e: Minenobu won the favor of Ienobu TOKUGAWA, the Shogun, and he later got independent as "Hamacho Family," which was ranked as one of the "Inner Court Painter Family."
Minenobu won the favor of the shogun, Ienobu Tokugawa, and he later gained independence as "Hamacho Family," which was ranked as one of the inner court painter families.
Minenobu won the favor of the Shogun Ienobu TOKUGAWA, and he later gained independence as 'Hamacho family,' which was ranked as one of the inner court painter families.
sen.cmt: 括弧修正苗字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: このほか、狩野興以（? - 1636）は狩野家の血族ではないが、探幽ら3兄弟の師匠筋にあたる人物で、その功績によって狩野姓を与えられ、後に紀州徳川家に仕えている。
sen.e: Besides them, Koi KANO (? - 1636) was not related by blood to the Kano family, but he was a master of Tan'yu and his brothers, and he was allowed to use the surname of Kano due to his achievement, and then worked for the Kishu Tokugawa Family.

Besides them, Koi Kano (? - 1636) was not related by blood to the Kano family but was a master of Tan'yu and his brothers; he was allowed to use the surname of Kano due to his achievement, and then worked for the Kishu Tokugawa Family.

Besides them, Koi KANO (date of birth unknown - 1636) was not related by blood to the Kano family but, along with his brothers, was a master of Tanyu; he was allowed to use the surname of Kano due to his achievements, and he worked for the Kishu Tokugawa family.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。 ? → date of birth unknownとしました。

sen.j: 一方、京都に残って活動を続けた「京狩野」という一派もあり、狩野永徳の弟子であった狩野山楽（1559 - 1635）がその中心人物である。
sen.e: Meanwhile, a group called "Kyo Kano" stayed active in Kyoto, and Sanraku KANO (1559 - 1635), a disciple of Eitoku KANO, was the pillar of the group.
Meanwhile, a group called "Kyo Kano" remained active in Kyoto, and Sanraku Kano (1559 - 1635), a disciple of Eitoku Kano, was the pillar of the group.
Meanwhile, a group called 'Kyo Kano' remained active in Kyoto, and Sanraku KANO (1559 - 1635), a disciple of Eitoku KANO, was the pillar of the group.
sen.cmt: 括弧修正苗字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 山楽は豊臣秀吉の家臣であった近江の木村家の出で、元の名を木村光頼と言った。
sen.e: Sanraku was from the Kimura clan in Omi, the vassal of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI, and his original name was Mitsuyori KIMURA.
Sanraku was from the Kimura clan in Omi, the vassal of Hideyoshi Toyotomi; his original name was Mitsuyori Kimura.
Sanraku was from the Kimura clan in Omi, the vassal of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI; his original name was Mitsuyori KIMURA.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 京都・大覚寺宸殿の障壁画『牡丹図』『紅白梅図』が代表作で、金地に色彩豊かで装飾的な画面を展開している。
sen.e: His best works are "Peonies" and "Red and White Plum Trees" in the main house in Kyoto Daikaku-ji Temple, and they have colorful and decorative pictures on the golden base.
His best works are "Peonies" and "Red and White Plum Trees" in the main house of Kyoto Daikaku-ji Temple, and they have colorful and decorative pictures on a golden base.
His best works are "Peonies" and "Red and White Plum Trees" in the main house of Kyoto Daikaku-ji Temple, and they have colorful and decorative pictures on a golden base.

sen.j: 山楽の娘婿で養子の狩野山雪（1589/90 - 1651）は、妙心寺天球院障壁画のほか、屏風絵などの現存作がある。
sen.e: Sansetsu KANO (1589/90 - 1651), the husband of Sanraku's daughter, created the paintings on partitions in Tenkyuin, Myoshin-ji Temple as well as some paintings of folding screens, which are existent.

Sansetsu Kano (1589/90 - 1651), the husband of Sanraku's daughter, created the paintings on partitions in Tenkyuin, Myoshin-ji Temple as well as some paintings of folding screens, which are still in existence.

Sansetsu KANO (1589/90 - 1651), the husband of Sanraku's daughter, created the screen paintings in Tenkyuin, Myoshin-ji Temple as well as some paintings of folding screens, which are still in existence.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。"paintings on partitions" → "screen paintings"

sen.j: 樹木、岩などの独特の形態、徹底した細部描写など、狩野派の絵師の中では異色の個性的な画風をもつ。
sen.e: He had distinctive painting style, unique among painters of the Kanoha group, such as distinct shapes of trees and rocks, and complete details.
He had a distinctive painting style unique among painters of the Kanoha group, such as distinct shapes of trees and rocks, as well as the completeness of detail.
He had a distinctive painting style unique among painters of the Kanoha group, such as distinct shapes of trees and rocks, as well as the completeness of detail.

sen.j: 山雪の残した画論を、子の狩野永納（1631 - 1697）がまとめたものが、日本人による本格的な絵画史としては最初のものとされる『本朝画史』である。
sen.e: The essay on paintings made by Sansetsu and edited by his son Eino KANO (1631 - 1697) is "Honchogashi," the first full-fledge painting history book by the Japanese.
The essay on paintings made by Sansetsu and edited by his son Eino Kano (1631 - 1697) is "Honchogashi," the first full-fledge painting history book by a Japanese.
The essay on paintings made by Sansetsu and edited by his son Eino KANO (1631 - 1697) is entitled "Honchogashi," the first full-fledge painting history book by a Japanese.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 木挽町家からは、江戸時代後期に狩野典信（えいせんいんみちのぶ、1730 - 1790）、狩野惟信（ようせんいんこれのぶ、1753 - 1808）、狩野栄信（いせんいんながのぶ、1775 - 1828）、狩野養信（せいせんいんおさのぶ、1786 - 1846）などが出ている。
sen.e: The Kobikicho Family produced Michinobu KANO (Michinobu EISEN'IN 1730 - 1790), Korenobu KANO (Korenobu YOSEN'IN 1753 - 1808), Naganobu KANO (Naganobu ISEN'IN 1775 - 1828), Osanobu KANO (Osanobu SEISEN'IN 1786 - 1846) in the late Edo era.

The Kobikicho Family produced Michinobu Kano (Michinobu Eisen'in (1730 - 1790), Korenobu Kano (Korenobu Yosen'in (1753 - 1808), Naganobu Kano (Naganobu Isen'in (1775 - 1828) and Osanobu Kano (Osanobu Seisen'in (1786 - 1846) during the late Edo period.

The Kobikicho family produced Michinobu KANO (Michinobu EISENIN (1730 - 1790)), Korenobu KANO (Korenobu YOSENIN (1753 - 1808)), Naganobu KANO (Naganobu ISENIN (1775 - 1828)) and Osanobu KANO (Osanobu SEISENIN (1786 - 1846)) during the late Edo period.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 晴川院養信は、天保9年（1838年）と同15年（1844年）に相次いで焼失した江戸城の西の丸および本丸御殿の再建に際し、膨大な障壁画の制作を狩野派の棟梁として指揮した。
sen.e: Osanobu SEISEN'IN led creation of numerous painting on partitions as a master when reconstructuring Nishinomaru and Honmaru Palace of Edo Castle, burned down in succession in 1838 and 1844.

Osanobu Seisen'in led the creation of numerous painting on partitions as a master during the reconstruction of the Nishinomaru and Honmaru palaces of Edo Castle, which had burned down in succession in 1838 and 1844.

Osanobu SEISENIN led the creation of numerous screen paintings as a master of the Kanoha group during the reconstruction of the Nishinomaru and Honmaru palaces of Edo Castle, which had burned down in 1838 and again in 1844.
sen.cmt: paintingsとしました Kanoha group追加しました。"paintings on partitions" → "screen paintings"

sen.j: 障壁画そのものは現存しないが、膨大な下絵が東京国立博物館に所蔵されている。
sen.e: Though the paintings are not existent, numerous designs are in the possession of the Tokyo National Museum.
Though the paintings are no longer in existence, numerous designs are in the possession of the Tokyo National Museum.
Although the paintings are no longer in existence, numerous designs are in the possession of the Tokyo National Museum.

sen.j: 晴川院は古画の模写や収集にも尽力した。
sen.e: SEISEN'IN also made efforts to copy and collect ancient paintings.
Seisen'in also made efforts to copy and collect ancient paintings.
SEISENIN also endeavored to copy and collect ancient paintings.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 一般に、江戸時代後期の狩野派絵師に対する評価はあまり高くないが、20世紀後半以降の研究の進展により、晴川院は古典絵画から幕末の新しい絵画の動きまで熱心に研究した、高い技術をもった絵師であったことが認識されるようになり、再評価の動きがある。
sen.e: Though the painters of the Kanoha group in the late Edo era are not well appreciated generally, there is a move to reappraise SEISEN'IN as the progress of the study after the late 20th century recognizes that he was a painter with good technique, eagerly studying from ancient paintings to the new painting movement in the end of the Edo era.

Though the painters of the Kanoha group in the late Edo period are not well appreciated generally, there is a move to reappraise Seisen'in as the progress of the study after the late twentieth century recognizes that he was a painter with good technique, eagerly studying art from ancient paintings and on to the new painting movement at the end of the Edo period.

Although the painters of the Kanoha group in the late Edo period are not well appreciated generally, there is a move to reappraise SEISENIN as the progress of the study after the late twentieth century recognizes that he was a painter with good technique who eagerly studied art from ancient paintings and on to the new painting movement at the end of the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。Though →Although に変更しました。

sen.j: 晴川院の次代の狩野雅信（しょうせんいんただのぶ、1823 - 1880）の門下には、明治初期の日本画壇の重鎮となった狩野芳崖（下関出身、1828 - 1888）と橋本雅邦（川越出身、1835 - 1908）がいた。
sen.e: Hogai KANO (born in Shimonoseki, 1828 - 1888), a leading figure of the Japanese art world in the early Meiji era, and Gaho HASHIMOTO (born in Kawagoe, 1835 - 1908) were disciples of Tadanobu KANO (Tadanobu SHOSEN'IN 1823 - 1880), the next generation of SEISEN'IN.

Hogai Kano (born in Shimonoseki, 1828 - 1888), a leading figure of the Japanese art world in the early Meiji period, as well as Gaho Hashimoto (born in Kawagoe, 1835 - 1908) were disciples of Tadanobu Kano (Tadanobu Shosen'in 1823 - 1880), the next generation of Seisen'in.

Hogai KANO (born in Shimonoseki, 1828 - 1888), a leading figure of the Japanese art world during the early Meiji period, like Gaho HASHIMOTO (born in Kawagoe, 1835 - 1908), was a disciple of Tadanobu KANO (Tadanobu SHOSEN'IN 1823 - 1880), the next generation of SEISENIN.
sen.cmt: 苗字を大文字にしました。

sen.j: 芳崖と雅邦はともに地方の狩野派系絵師の家の出身であった。
sen.e: Both Hogai and Gaho were from painter families of the Kanoha group.
Both Hogai and Gaho were from painter families of the Kanoha group.
Both Hogai and Gaho were from painter families of the Kanoha group.

sen.j: 職業絵師集団としての狩野派は、パトロンであった江戸幕府の終焉とともにその歴史的役目を終えた。
sen.e: The historical role of the Kanoha group as a professional painter group finished as their patron Edo Shogunate ended.
The historical role of the Kanoha group as a professional painter group finished as its patron, the Edo shogunate, ended.
The historical role of the Kanoha group as a professional painter group finished as its patron, the Edo shogunate, ended.
